So if you're looking for a decentromance anime to pass your time. Then I suggest this.

“Mediocre!” Dude got his face ripped off (Mad Max Fury Road)
After this past season, I think it’s fair to assume that romantic comedy anime has finally reached its point of saturation. Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai, or, Tada Never Falls in Love as the gringos say, is perhaps the most blatant lie ever told through a title since “The Last Jedi”. “Tada-koi”, for short, is an “original” concept birthed out of Doga Kobo and helmed by Mitsue Yamazaki, who is perhaps most known for having directed “Monthly Girls’ Nozaki-kun”, a much more ambitious and consistent project than Tada-koi could ever hope to be. For amyriad of reasons, Tada-koi will perhaps go down as one of the most rote by numbers contemporary romantic comedy anime to ever do it. If this is the new standard for “original” concepts moving forward, then it’s best to temper expectations for any shows in the future that fall under that banner. 


As far as technical aspects alone go, it was lobbed the biggest soft-ball you could potentially throw an anime of its ilk. Doga Kobo has more or less proven that they can handle projects of this nature, and Tada-koi remained fairly consistent throughout its run in terms of overall polish. Unfortunately, as Yamazaki has proven with previous projects that he’s been at the helm for, his direction is fairly orthodox. Tada-koi lacks any sense of personality as far as visual direction, which for a romantic comedy can dramatically affect its watchability. Doga typically saturates every frame with fun visual quirks to add to what would otherwise be a standard show. Take Himouto Umara-chan for instance, it was practically the only good thing about that show. Tada-koi didn’t really hedge its bets on visual quirks as much as it relied on its cast of “charming” characters to convey the “Com” in the “Rom”. The only problem is that all of these characters are so trite and onenote that their gags never extracted much more than a shallow giggle from me.  


Tada and Teresa are really the only two characters worth expounding on, however let me try and sell you this laundry list of a supporting cast. There’s the zany childhood friend (oooh that rascal, he’s so funny! He even talks funny!), and he comes with his own stuck-up badass tsundere girl he’s crushing on to seal the deal! Not much of a sell? Okay, how about the stern class president who’s really an unspoken beauty, I’ll even throw in that pervy ol’ Senpai with the matching glasses to boot, you get the complete set! No? Alright, I didn’t want have to pull this one out, but there’s no way you’re NOT gonna want the hunky foreign rival childhood friend character to absolutely trivialize the conflict! He’s perfect in every way! ...No?...Feisty Imouto?...Did I mention there’s a talking cat? The “supporting” cast couldn’t even fill their roles properly, because that’s just it, they were written to populate the show, not support the main characters like they were supposed to. 


I never really bought in to the fact that Tada was anything more than a normal guy because nothing in the show really lead me to believe that he was suffering from any form of “emotional constipation”. The impression I got was that his backstory was really just shoehorned in last second because they needed some way to arbitrarily develop his character when the time came. It was commendable to try and include some form of emotional complexity for the main protagonist, but since the show was more concerned with meandering along with a cookiecutter cast, it was a subplot that didn’t amount to anything substantial. He did reasonably well filling the role of the straight man but I expected a lot more complexity out of the initial set-up of his characterization. 


If I had little to say about Tada, I have even less to say about Teresa. Really her only defining character traits is that she’s nice and she’s bubbly. But as Hachiman Hikigaya once pointed out “I hate nice girls, because they’re nice to everyone and not just me.” (I’m sure I botched that quote, you don’t have to tell me) Teresa and Tada really don’t have that believable of chemistry at all. I contend with people that Tada could’ve been any ol’ Joe-Schmoe off the streets with the decency to help a foreigner out in their time of need, and Teresa probably would’ve become smitten with them as well. 


Perhaps my biggest grievance that I hold against this show’s writing was how poorly it was paced. It didn’t hit me until I got to the 11th episode where the two main characters in question were put in a date scenario seemingly out of nowhere. Tada and Teresa never interacted in that meaningful of a way up to that point which makes their chemistry as love interests come off as all the more forced. It’s almost as if the staff realized this and made a mad-dash for the finish before anyone could notice. The last handful of episodes aside, none of the episodes particularly showcased any significant development between the main couple and was instead concerned with regurgitating dime-a-dozen slice of life antics, which would be fine if this series had a longer run. You can certainly pick and choose moments here and there however Tada-koi was so unconcerned with ACTIVELY and properly developing the relationship between it’s two focal points, Tada and Teresa, that it halts the entire pacing of the show. 


By design, “rom-coms” tend to be the most predictable of anime so I hold execution and personability over most other criteria. Tada-koi was unfathomably disappointing in both regards.  Another drop in the bucket for mediocre seasonal rom-com anime. If reading this show’s premise gives you the feeling that you have this show figured out...it’s probably because you do. When the best character of your rom-com was a friggin cat, you know something’s gone horribly awry.

Anime covers many genres and take a lot of inspiration from other animes, mangas, light novels, books etc and at some point from these inspirations cliches can be born. I will be honest as a reviewer, I expected something cliched but enjoyable when I first saw the trailer. I was very pleasantly surprised when even within the well tread genres of romantic comedies, this anime in terms of story, art and music actually pushed for something out of the norm.
Since I first saw the trailer and till now(6th episode), the story line and character development has really been well done and I would definitely recommendthis anime to watch for anyone who loves light hearted rom-coms like me.\n\n
P.S. I really have to say this but this anime really reminds me of the movie Roman Holiday. Same princess running away to a foreign country, a photographer who does not know the story yet harbours the princess and then a short lived but powerful romance developing. I do not know how this story will end but I hope that this story has as powerful and emotional ending as Roman Holiday.

The problem was never resolved so it seemed like a cop-out. Overall, it was enjoyable. Lovely story, art, and development. Only the ending was too quick and needed more complete closure.

"Tada-kun Never Falls in Love" was a beautiful series; it was a pleasure to watch, making me laugh, making me cry at times, and making me happy to be privileged enough to watch this wonderful anime. 
In terms of why I gave this anime a 9/10:
The story was solid and enjoyable, although predictable I still wanted to keep on watching. The artwork was stunning and a pleasure for the eyes. The sound was enjoyable, and the music fitted perfectly. The only let down was that the character development felt a bit shallow, and the last few episodes felt rushed after the slow Slice of Lifepace in the previous episodes.\n\n
However, this was a wonderfully entertaining show, I am sincerely happy I watched it.\n

Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai might be the first anime review I've written in a while. First of all, I myself believe that the story has soo many potential to be developed IF the anime want to do more than 13 episodes. The anime had a potential to be that one of the anime with slow burns romance, filled with every day life and friendships. Kinda like the romcoms of western series, I think? But hey, I'm not saying on how they conclude the series is bad (i quite enjoyed it actually), but it's pity they took a 'mediocre' route instead of doing something new.
Theart may be the very first reason why I watched the anime in the first place. It made me missed Gekkan Shoujo Nozaki-kun so much :( and the atmosphere of the artwork is just peaceful and relaxing, which I really enjoyed. 


The music and BGMs of the series is on-point but not quite memorable, they produced a music that made you want to sit back in a relaxing manner while probably enjoyed a hot chocolate on a rainy day while watching it. Again, like the artwork, it's peaceful and relaxing.


I really like the characters actually?? They're pretty solid and some of them felt very 'real', like I could see my friends in them. An opinion, but I really like Ijuin's character. He's this character that made you want to smack his head but still want to gave him a hug or a simple pat on the shoulder. Much like I'd do to my real life best friends. 


The seiyuus are the reasons I stayed though. Especially Tada's seiyuu which is Nakamura Yuuichi. Nakamura Yuuichi delivered a very great acting by becoming a simple high schooler, he somehow managed to bring Tada-kun to life. Tada is a very simple character and to see how Yuukyan executed him to life without being dramatic is just gorgeous. 


Overall, this is a great anime for you guys who want to do some relaxing binge-watches at the end of the day (or semester, like me). Don't think about the storyline too much and I assured you, this could be one of the anime that could bring a smile to your face after a tiring day.

Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai is an original anime by Doga Kobo. And, for what it is, it's cute, but very cliche and predictable. 
If you watched any amount of romance anime, k-dramas, or even western media, you could probably guess how the whole storyline plays out without even watching it. 
- Boy meets girl
- Girl is incredibly good looking
- She is also the new exchange student in boy's class
-Couple bond together
-Another person comes in to test the main couple
- Circumstances pull them apart
- Couple sits around and mops until one of them does something
- Leading man crashes the wedding and pronounces his love forthe heroine\n
- Girl breaks off the bad engagement\n
- Couple gets back together. \n
-The end\n\n
Don't get me wrong. Having a predictable story isn't automatically a bad thing, since most stories about the journey not the destination and everything has been done before in some form or another. However, the other elements of the story are nothing to write home about either. \n\n
The two leads are charming and likeable, but needed more development. The side characters are charming, but nothing super special outside of Nyanko Big (the cat). I feel the side characters needed more focus as well.  \n\n
As others pointed out, the story doesn't do a fantastic job at selling the romance either. Tada acts stoic and warms up to our lead. Teresa acts bubbly, growing found of him. Outside of them spending time together and Tada kinda getting feelings for her later on, there isn't much else to it. The side romances are hardly explored. And the anime suffers for it. Audience investment is crucial for a story like this.\n\n
There are good things about this anime. The art and sound direction are good. None of the characters annoyed me. I found the episode told in Nyanko Big's POV funny. I love the OP. I give the anime credit for not making Charles, the rival love interest, evil or unlikable like what often happens in stories like this. \n\n
Over all, like I said before, it's just a cute anime. Nothing more. And there are far better romance anime out there that I could recommend over this one. \n\n
(As a side note, there's no English dub for this. Only the subs. Just as a heads up if anyone needs to know that) \n\n
Story: 5 \n
Art: 7\n
Sound: 6\n
Character: 5\n
Enjoyment: 6\n
Overall: 5 \n

- Finally, my review of Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai, starting with the story, which is interesting and unique, the story begins a bit bland, seeming to be a romantic comedy, but is improving every episode; in general, the story is simply astonishing, as she has been able to turn a simple romantic comedy into something much more remarkable.
- On the technical side, without doubt is one of the points in which the series most stands out, the technical part is simply sensational, both its animation and especially its visual, are dazzling and perfectly match the theme of the series; another point that Tada-kun standsout in is his soundtrack that is simply unforgettable, an excellent soundtrack; now speaking a little of the direction, which a complicated case, because in some episodes the direction sins a lot, already in other episodes the direction goes very well, finally, the direction as a whole is Ok.


- Now speaking a little of the characters, unfortunately many of them were not properly exploited and developed, although still the series has an excellent cast of characters, all are very charismatic and captivating, highlighting the protagonists that these sim were well developed along of the series, in short, as a whole Tada-kun has great characters.


- Conclusion, Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai is simply the best romantic comedy of the spring season 2018, which although finished a bit open, the anime as a whole was simply excellent; the series has a dazzling technical part, as well as a surprising and interesting story, good characters and excellent characters, plus a good direction and great soundtrack, without doubt one of my favorite anime this year so far, and without doubt I recommend Tada -kun wa Koi wo Shinai, a simply spectacular anime !! 💜😍🌸 !!

Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai is an original anime by Doga Kobo and to be honest dosen't live upto its name. I'm not going to give a detailed review on this one because in my opinion it is not worth it. This review contains the plot in detail though I won't call those spoilers as you will anyway guess every inch of it when you start watching this series.
Nothing could be expected about the story because this is an 'ORIGINAL' anime. The originality of this anime astounds me. A protagonist who lost his parents in an accident meets a foreign princess who has come abroadto study in his school along with Miss Helper who is also posing as a transfer student. Then prince charming comes to Japan for his princess and the protagonist wins her heart against him. Oh and there is also another guy who can't identify his childhood friend he sees everyday without her glasses and falls in love with the non-spectacle version of her. These traditional characters are knitted together using photography which everyone except the protagonist does for fun. I can't seem to find why there is a comedy tag on this anime just like the misleading title. "Tada-kun has Never Tasted Love" is a much better series and would have helped judge the cliche story line before this even came out. This anime however dosen't stray away from the focus on the relationships among the not so new characters but these relationships are also in no way new to the anime community.\n
I rate this series an overall 4/10 as it is watchable however is just a mix up of other anime which are again mix ups of older anime.

MC's childhood friend who is just a terribly annoying guy. The club president who is a walking otaku cliche. There's also a underclassman of the MC who's similar to a dog.
And then there's the Heroine. There are 4 more or less relevant girls in the show and unfortunately the main Heroine is the most annoying, unintelligent, uninteresting and least attractive one of them. The other3 girls (MC's sister, Club member, Heroine's friend) are ok.\n\n

If you are wondering wether you should watch this show, the most important question you should ask yourself is: am I a hopeless, sappy romantic? If you're like me and your answer to this question is: yes, definately, then this show might just be the thing for you.
This show isn't particularly original, and I get the feeling that it really does not try to be, which I think is perfectly fine. There are many anime that try so hard to be different, that they are forgetting about the most important thing of all: entertainment. But as I am really not trying to start a discussionon that subject, I'll just move on to my actual review for this show.


Story: 7

Like I mentioned above, this show is definately not the most original. The same can be said about the story. It basically is your typical boy meets girl (or the other way around) kinda setting. Naturally, our main couple need several episodes to get to know each other, and they both have an interesting background, which influences their relationship greatly. I didn't mind the slower pacing of the show, But I can imagine there will be people that do. In the end, I got exactly what I expected, storywise, and I don't really think that's a bad thing, as I generally don't watch anime to be surprised, but to be entertained, and in this particular genre, to satisfy the part of my soul that used to belong to a young maiden, experiencing love for the first time. 


Art: 7

I don't actually have a strong opinion on the art in this anime. I appreciate that it's not overly cutesy, but it is not special in any way. It get's the job done though. 


Sound: 8

The soundtrack is well chosen in my opinion. In these types of shows, the soundtrack really needs to support the emotion, conveyed in any given scene. I find that in sappy romantic shows like this one, a simple piano melody is often enough to strengthen the feels, coming at you from every direction. In my case, when I really notice a soundtrack, it's either really good or really bad. In this show, the music did exactly what it needed to do.


Characters: 9

And now we're getting to the good part. The characters in this show start out to be the same as the characters in all the other romance shows you know and love, with one exception: Tada-kun himself. If there is one thing I absolutely hate in romance anime, it's a main character that is an awkward mess, get's beaten to a pulp by the heroine for walking in on her while she's changing, and just can't decide which of the dozen dropdead gorgeous girls that surround him is most worthy of his attention. Not because he want to bang them all, mind you, but because he just thinks they are all swell people and he doesn't want to hurt anyone. If I want to watch someone hopelessly ruin his lovelife by being an indecisive idiot, I'd just recap my own sad disasters that I call "relationships". Tada is a hard working, down to earth kinda guy, and that is why I like him. The main heroine is of the basic airhead variety, untill you find out later that there is actually way more to her than that. But the one who really stood out to me was dear, sweet Kaoru-kun. After watching the first episode, I absolutely hated this guy. He was just plain annoying. But after finishing the show, he actually came close to being my favorite character on the show. That's what decent character development can do for you. I would have loved for some of the other characters to have been given more attention, but I'm just happy that they gave decent screentime to characters other than the main couple. The whole duration of the show, I was nervously waiting for the evil, underhanded other love rival (either male or female) to come along and ruin the cast, but in the end, they never came.


Enjoyment: 9

Like I said at the beginning, if you are like me, and you have a giddy middle school girl hidden away in your heart somewhere, chances are you are gonna like this show. It tries to give you a lovely romance, with a bit of comedy and drama, and it does exactly that. The supporting cast is balanced, the dramatic parts are well written and the main characters are likeable. One last bit of critique at the very end, would be that the comedic relieve sometimes just doesn't work. the show excels in the dramatic parts and if you want to watch a great comedy, you should probably be reading some Gintama reviews or something. This show tugs on your heartstrings in several ways, and if you're the type of person who like shows like that, I suggest you give this one a chance. 


I tried to keep this review short and probably failed miserably. My closing argument for liking this show is that I knew exactly what I was getting into when I started it, end it just did not disappoint. If you actually took the time to read my opinion on this show, I am very grateful to you, and if it convinced you to give this show a try, then it was definately worth writing it.

This anime is nothing special. It really isn't, I walked in expecting this basic romance story and that is exactly what I got. 
Now that doesn't mean the anime was bad, if anything I actually suggest watching it. I'm someone who enjoys romance stories, I've watched a few here and there... yea, just a few.
This one was different yet the same. I'm someone who likes the plain everyday MCs, it's who I connect the most with. Though, I felt something different from this MC that I didn't from others, be it Toradora, Angel Beats, Anohana, etc. 
I guess I felt he was larger than me.A common theme is the MC facing their fears and overcoming the differences between them to become a pair. 


It's told to you early on what is going to happen and I loved it. I knew from like episode 1 or 2 what was going to happen at the end of the story and how it would get there. Half because it is your basic ordinary story and half because foreshadowing. 


A story based on fear and regrets, common.

A character base riddled with mundane characters, common.

The sound, common.

The art style, bit above average.


So why 6?


I'll reiterate my point of the MC feeling bigger than me. I connect with him because I understand the final emotions. I resonate with his foley and find myself enthralled with the actions. 


Can you face your fears of the unknown to speak your mind to the one you love?

Can you fly to a place you never been to, a place of strangers for the person you love?

Can you actually admit your learn from your regrets?


I can safely say, No.


That's why I always connect with these MCs, he did what I couldn't. I recommend the show, it's a nice time waster.

If you ever saw a bouquet made of just silk and wrapping paper, you can always think it is beautiful from afar but as you come close, realizing that bouquet isn't real flower, it dooms to you that you can not actually enjoy it as real flowers. Yet, you still like that bouquet enough to keep it on your desk.
Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai was a rather great to start show. Completely predictable, but great to start, just like that bouquet of silk and wraps.
Where haven't we all meet a story about an someone coming to Japan, fall in love with a Japanese before? Well,I haven't seen that many romances, on screen and in real life, but I have seen enough of such stories. And yes, it was predictable. I was able to find out a key plot in 1 episode and even figured out the ending from episode 10. I'm not trying to boast, but it was that predictable. All that is to not mention all those hints you get from the start of story with so many other pairing and their own stories. In fact, it is exactly because of how predictable it was, the series was actually enjoyable for once.


However, it still manages to start off beautifully enough to have me kept on watching. And by beautiful, I mean the work on visual and sound/music was excellent. It sure did paint the whole series in the color of love, a faint pink like, yet some what green and purple, all the while manages to hide some very hard to see red, blue, black and even white mixture of color. Although not exactly it, it still has enough to make up for a rainbow. I myself think this is why the plot is so centered on rainbow. Despite my liking on it, the over all pink-ish color was actually not all that good, all thing considered.


Yes, that pink-ish color is too perfect that it went too far from my common sense. Especially, that one character: Charles - the best nice guy you can find out there. While the rest of characters, considering their screen time, all have something unique to them, Charles is only a nice guy. From start, to the end. Even in before the start, he was a nice guy. So much I gave a whole 3 more points just for him in character category. He gave up a lot, even for a nice guy. In fact, I started to think that he was actually a coward and wanted a way out of everything by giving up. So, in a sense, Charles was the best character in the series in my opinion, considering what back story he might have.


Talking about back stories, we still don't know what most other pairings since the whole thing was very rushed. Which, is a shame, since this kind of story line fits for a slower development. There are also scenes I don't remember seeing among flashbacks so I actually thought it was originally a novel or Manga adaptation right then and there.


To sum it up, 

- Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai was a rather great series at start, but was rushed and written with so many cliche development.

- However, it still hits on what the viewers want to see to land on safe zone, time and time again. Considering how many chances it got.

- After all is seen and talked, it was a fair series to enjoy. But not enough to actually like it.

Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai is a school-romance but it doesn't feel rehashed, it's quite atmospheric and even charming at times. The characters, plot and story are all cliched but the show as a whole somehow isn't.
There's no sexualisation and it's very light on fan service, you can avoid it all by skipping ahead 4 minutes at the midway point of episode 5 and you won't miss anything important.
The show is consistently funny but obnoxiously annoying in places too. It’s ridiculous in many ways but it's not always clear whether that's intentional.
Despite being a slice of life, the story it tells has a very clearstart and finish, though it does leave some loose ends.\n\n
As far as school-romance anime goes, this is actually pretty good and I hope this is the direction the genre combination is going, but I would still only recommend it if you've already watched a lot of anime and just want something that's not terrible.

Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai is a bittersweet anime that has a cozy atmosphere all around the show.
Sadness, happiness, love, which are from those feelings that affect human most? 
You all have must have different answer each one of you. But after that you must be realize that those feelings are things that affect human most. Because they are .. Feeling.
This anime show us what it means for us as a human that have so much feeling while we living our life. In here, the protagonist of the story is started his story with deep sadness, and then as the time goes he feels morefeeling, like happiness, friendship, daily routine, and love. Even though after he feels all those feeling, that sadness that he feel so deeply is never forgotten. He know that from that sadness he found a point where it can be declare like this.\n\n
"If you can go back in time where you can make up your regret isn't it great?"\n
"But you can't"\n
"Isn't preventing repetition of the same regret better?"\n\n
These three statement hit me hard, it is true. I don't know if some of you also think the same way as the statement but for me its something new about how we should responsible against our regret. And thats what the makes the show great. \n\n
But beside that the rest of the show is kind of mediocre. Let me explain it.\n
The story and the character, to be fair it feels so mediocre. But its mediocre in good way and not in the bad way, so it is still fun to watch.\n
The art is smooth, it suit the anime so well.\n
The sound, ahh this one, I really love the sound in this anime, especially the piano soundtrack. I really really love it, it suit the atmosphere of the show so well. \n
PS : if someone know the anime that have same atmosphere as Tada-kun (i know there is i had watched it but forget what it is) with same melody like soundtrack in this anime, tell me!\n
You found this review helpful.

Alongside moe and action shonen, romance is probably the most oversaturated genre next to them, to the point that you could very well make a drinking game out of every example of these genres, pointing out the various tropes as they come out.  But sometimes you get examples where those tropes aren't necessarily a bad thing.  As such, we have Takakoi, a pretty box standard romance that wouldn't be the same without them.
Story:
Our story of Tadakoi starts with Mitsuyoshi Tada, a boy with an interest in photography who on one faithful encounter (there's one shot) meets an airheaded foreigner and guides her around to makesure she doesn't get lost in a foreign land.  A rainstorm and hiding from said rain scene later (there's another shot), it turns out that this foreigner is a new transfer student named Teresa Wagner, who, along with her 'friend' Alec Magritte is also Tada's new neighbor.  What a coincidence.


Tadakoi's storytelling and plot structure is nothing new.  Much of the series follows around the photography club, with extra emphasis on Tada and Teresa as the two slowly grow closer as the series progresses, leading to what you would probably expect after reading the synopsis and how much of a lie the title 'Tada-kun Never Falls in Love' is for the series.  Now that may seem like this series has no actual merit to it, as rehashing typical tropes in a story that's your standard crush to confession story, but that's only mostly the case here.


For starters, the show establishes information for our main characters very early own, making a really solid baseline that stays with the series for the rest of its runtime.  This one thing does wonders for the series, as it provides really good background and actually validates the romance to happen more so than just throwing characters together because 'this HAS to be a romance'.  Not only that, but the series is free from any melodrama, a trap that many romance-based shows fall to in order to create tension and more serious moments.  Tadakoi has hardly if any at all, making the more serious parts of the series more somber by comparison, and actually makes them pop out more because in doing so, the gravity of the situation becomes all the more apparent this way.


However despite that, Tadakoi has numerous plot threads that don't actually get touched upon as much as they should.  Both Teresa and Tada get the brunt of the screentime, leaving the rest of the cast and their subplots to get pushed to the side and/or not resolved.  At most, the side cast gets one episode to devote to their love story, but that's about it, and it doesn't really go very far.  While it doesn't intrude on the main story, it's one of those things that personally irked me because despite the satisfaction of the ending, I couldn't help but think the show had most of its plot threads unfinished, and that from a critical perspective is criminal, especially since they each had just as much potential to blossom into a story as much as Tadakoi did.  (Though in that sense, time constraints would be a problem.)


That being said, Tadakoi is overall a pretty average show that despite the 'average' description, sticks to its guns based with tropes that without, would've made the show crash and burn heavily.  It's a non-intrusive entry into the school romance genre, bearing some heavy elements without going full-on melodrama, mixed in with comedy to create a typically airy and bright atmosphere that was a joy to watch.  Loose plot threads are a bother, but the impact they have towards the series overall is minimal in the grand scheme of things.


Overview:

+ Great tone throughout

+ Uses tropes effectively

+ No melodrama

- Subplot threads are shaky at best


Characters:


Another bit of praise that Tadakoi deserves is in its cast.  Specifically, how difficult I find it is to actually dislike any member of the cast.


Mitsuyoshi Tada is our typically stoic protagonist with a passion for photography.  While he showcases more 'emotionless' traits than your typical romance protagonist, Tada is a remarkably interesting choice, as mentioned earlier, his backstory and reason for being come early on, and we get the scope of what kind of person he is from the very start.  This contributes much to his growth as a character, as his change catalyzes the climax that greatly validates the usage of that specific trope.  He's also not a dense motherfucker, and for a romance protagonist in any stretch of the imagination, that is a major plus.


Then there's Teresa, the more airheaded of the two who always wears a smile on her face and is obsessed with the 'Rainbow Shogun', a tv show figure that considers 'rainbow' as a color of the rainbow.  Sure.  From the start, it's clear that there's more to Teresa than meets the eye, which in typical anime fashion, gets revealed at the very end of the series to no one's surprise cause the signs are pretty obvious from just watching the show casually.  Nevertheless, just like Tada, Teresa gets some immediate backstory early on that helps with giving her the necessary depth to carry on through the series.  I mostly focus on this aspect because of their characters because it's really the penultimate reason to why the second half of the show happens in the first place.  There's an escalation within this show that really bolsters the show's themes of "Do, don't regret" that not only came out of left field, but made the show so much better than it could've been.


The side cast consists mostly of Tada and Teresa's friends: Pin-senpai, Yamashita, Hasegawa, Alec, and Ijuuin, as well as some more lesser used characters like Tada's little sister, Nyanko Big, a cat primarily used for gags, and Charles, who shows up later in the series.  The common theme for these characters is the fact that it's very difficult to find a reason to hate any of them.  Any negative traits a character may have is played off for laughs, and even then, their positive ones show themselves in spades, which is not only impressive, but makes the show more enjoyable cause it's a cast of characters that you don't want to hate.  I want to give special attention to Ijuuin and Charles though, as the show really could've easily gone the annoying best friend and super intense love rival route for the two, which really could've been possible, but instead opted for a really good best friend and respectable love rival that again, makes it really hard to make you hate them because they contribute more than they take away.


Overview:

+ Main duo carries development with them throughout the series

+ Side cast are all great characters

+ Better opted routes for some characters than they could've been


Art:


Produced by Doga Kobo, the art for Tadakoi is bright, colorful, and very 'cute', at least with Teresa's design.  (As expected of a company who primarily makes slice of life.)  The company's track record may not really stand out, but if there's one thing they're really good at, it's consistency.  Tadakoi has very consistent artwork and key frames/character models hardly look different from scene to scene and make everything look very seamless.


I'm also a big fan at the fact that the show rarely uses the more typical 'exaggerated faces' or any form of the trope to establish comedy.  Much of the comedy happens within the typical style of the show, and I find that to be a positive trait due to the current over-reliance on stuff like that in typical comedy series'.  Backgrounds are also privy to this benefit, as much of the show is very picturesque, fitting well with the show's photography theme.


Overview:

+ Consistent artwork

+ Very colorful and pleasing to look at


Sound:


Personally, I find the OP to be better than its ED counterpart.  Masayoshi Ooishi's "Otomodachi Film" is a very upbeat and catchy song that captures your attention the moment the song starts.  It sort of leads you into what to expect with Tadakoi, which is nice considering for this show, what you have on the box is what you're going to get.  By comparison though, "Love Song" is a seiyuu song sung by Teresa's VA, which by comparison isn't all that impressive, as it's a slow song with not many memorable qualities about it.


Personal Enjoyment:


"You get what you get".  I think that's about the easiest way to explain Tadakoi.  As the show is a road to confession story, just the mention of that plotline alone creates a simple roadmap that one who's seen enough shows of this nature can discern what can happen without even really watching the show.  Its reliance on tropes only bolsters this fact.


However, personally I don't find that to be a bad thing.  In a landscape where consumers try to find the 'next big thing', and tropes and lack of originality are seen as the devil as the phrase "We've seen it a million times" is thrown around casually, I actually welcomed Tadakoi for being a show that for all intents and purposes, just wanted to entertain with a sweet and simple romance that, while cliched, did at least follow through with what it set out to do in terms of the main couple.  Yes, there are glaring issues elsewhere, but that didn't really bother me too much.  This is mostly because personally, I have a livid hate for melodrama.  I've seen so many romance shows crash and burn at the mere existence of the term, and seeing a confession love story NOT have that was more than I could've ever asked for.  So yes, I did enjoy this, even if it wasn't that amazing of a show critically.


If you're looking for a very casual romance, this is a pretty safe bet to take.  Tadakoi has absolutely nothing intrusive about it and I actually found it to be a nice breather to watch week after week given some of the contents in my list.  Though I do wonder of the socioeconomic impact the decision made at the very end will have, but that's not really my concern.  Seriously though, as much of a pure 'average' this show has tacked onto it, that's not really a bad thing.  Lacking originality, sure, but personally I'm sick and tired of shows trying to be 'original', seeing what the end results can become by that logic.

Gee, this show is called Tada Never Falls in Love and has "Romance" in the tags. I wonder what will happen in this romance anime called Tada Never Falls in Love. Can you guess it? I sure as hell can't, my buddies! I would say this review contains spoilers, but... I think you would probably know most of what happens in this show even if I didn't spoil you, but here's the warning anyway.
Apparently, Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai was somewhat anticipated before coming out because it's made by Doga Kobo, the same studio with the same staff that gave us Gekkan Shoujo Nozaki-kun. Now,I haven't watched Nozaki-kun, I don't know what that show is about or if it's any good, but I know people like it and expected Tada-kun to be on the same vein, and judging by how lukewarm the reception to this one was, I assume it didn't quite hit the mark. I'm saying this just so you know that I'm not judging Tada-kun by how it compares to Nozaki-kun or anything like that, especially because I think it's pretty unfair to judge a show by how it compares to another instead of viewing it as its own thing. Sure, you can make comparisons to prove some points and whatnot, but if you're basing your criticisms mostly on that, you're not really giving the show a fair chance, are you? Well, it's not like Tada-kun is the most original show ever anyway, but that doesn't mean it can't be good despite not being exactly original or groundbreaking, Boku no Hero Academia isn't exactly the most original shounen ever, but it's still a pretty good watch because it executes its shounen tropes and clichés very well. So, is Tada-kun a good show in that sense? Well... Kinda. It has some great production values and looks gorgeous, most Doga Kobo shows I watched do, the background art is very well-made and the animations are incredibly smooth, though the characters don't look exactly unique, but they look good enough.


The main character is Tada Mitsuyoshi, a japanese high school student who is a member of his school's Photography Club and aspires to be a photographer like his father was, Tada has never known love before. One certain day, Tada was taking some pics of the cherry blossoms for the club, but some dumb blonde bitch who's probably a gaijin was getting in the way of his pics and Tada was about to tell her to fuck off back to Sweden, but then the girl turned around and she actually looks cute, so it's alright, cute girls can stay in our glorious nippon lands. In this exact moment when Tada meets the foreign girl, the screen gets covered in a pink filter as cherry blossoms float around, which means the title of the show should have been Tada Takes A Minute to Fall in Love. Anyway, the girl asks Tada to take some pictures of her, he ends up taking with his own camera because her camera's battery died or whatever. The girl's name is Teresa Wagner, she's a foreigner from European country called Larsenburg, Teresa likes Japan a lot and is particularly a big fan of a japanese samurai-themed TV show called Rainbow Shogun, she just arrived in Japan and got separated from her travelling companion, so Tada lends her a hand and takes her to the Tada Cafe where he works together with his grandpa and his sister Yui. Fortunately, and conveniently, the hotel where Teresa will stay with her companion is right next to Tada's family cafe, also Teresa's companion is a redhead chick called Alexandra Magritte, but better known as Alec, who was worried sick and takes care of her, to the point of beating up one of Tada's friends because she misunderstood him as a creepy dude who was trying to make some moves on Teresa. Can you guess who Teresa could possibly be? I can't for the life of me, man...


Turns out Teresa and Alec are transfer students in Tada's school, and they end up joining the Photography Club as well. Most of the other main characters are also members of the club and they all follow some typical anime tropes: There's Ijuin Kaoru, the goofy hyperactive narcisist who's popular with girls, the president of the club, Sugimoto Hajime or Pin-senpai, who's a perverted third year student that's way into photographing nude girls and has an obsession with a gravure idol called Hina, Yamashita Kentarou, a first year student behaves like a dog for some reason, and then there's Hasegawa Hinako who's a bit of a quiet glasses girl and looks an awful lot like Hina... I wonder why Hinako looks like Hina. Can you guess it? Alright, that joke has gotten annoying now, I'll stop. Not that Tada, Teresa and Alec don't follow some anime tropes as well, Tada is your typical stoic protagonist, Teresa is the friendly childish girl and Alec is a bit of a tsundere, in fact none of the characters from Tada-kun is exactly original by any means, it doesn't help much that most of them don't get much development and don't show many character traits besides the ones you've seen since the beginning, but... I actually like Tada-kun's cast, at least most of it. I don't really care much for Yamashita Dog, Pin-senpai and Hinako, they don't really develop much, most of their scenes are typical hit-and-miss anime comedy, there's like, one episode dedicated to Pin-senpai and Hinako, also another one that shows Yui has a crush on Yamashita, but then the show never really bothers to explore these characters' relationships more, so I feel it was kind of a waste, I think Nyanko Big, Tada's cat, has a better romance arc than most of the characters this show wastes no time with starting to ship, which is weird. Being a slice of life, Tada-kun doesn't have much of a plot, it's just the Photography Club doing their club activities while Tada and Teresa get closer to each other and occasionally we get some focus on other characters, the pacing is not very good because there's a few episodes where nothing really happens when it comes to the characters and their relationships, and obviously there's no way to effectively develop many love couples in a 13 episode anime. 


That being said, Tada-kun would benefit to have more moments when other characters stop playing their anime trope for the sake of comedy, I feel this show really does a good job at making them likeable when it shows other sides of characters such as Ijuin and Alec. At first, I found Ijuin to be annoying because he's even the type of real-life person I wouldn't get along with at all, he's loud, hyperactive, he overreacts to stuff, loves taking pictures of himself and talking about himself, he constantly provokes Alec into beating him up, etc. But then one episode about him hosting a "show" of his own where he treats everyone else from the club with whatever they like to eat, showed that behind Ijuin's silly behavior, there's a great guy who deeply cares for his friend and pulls all this goofy act up just to amuse him and the others, he got moved by the fact that Tada's parents died and has been trying his best to cheer Tada up even nowadays when he's pretty alright, he still does it every year just so Tada and his other friends can have some fun. Now this is how you write a good comic relief character, people, I love it when this type of character gets their chance to show that they're more than just a a way to inject some comedy into the show, it makes me sympathize with them and even tolerate their silly moments, and Ijuin actually has quite a handful of serious moments where he's shown to be a very good friend, I didn't expect him of all people to be my favorite character in this show. Alec is also pretty cute when she's not playing the typical tsundere role with Ijuin, although she can get a bit overly dramatic at times when something happens to Teresa, I think it makes sense because she's not very good at expressing or controlling her feelings and cares a lot for Teresa's well-being, she's an alright character, I actually prefer her to Teresa, who's honestly kinda bland, but not unlikeable at least. Tada is also an alright character, he gets some development as he starts to realize his own feelings for Teresa, he has an internal conflict with that due to his backstory and the fact that Teresa will have to return to her country someday and his interactions with Ijuin are some quality bro shit, for a stoic anime protagonist I found him pretty easy to like compared to a lot of the others.


There's also a new character that gets introduced in the second half of the show, Charles de Loire, a descendant of French nobility who's later revealed to be secretly Teresa's fiance, and you'd probably think this show would turn into a shitty love triangle drama where the main character has to dispute the girl with some douchebag the writers clearly want you to hate. Surprisingly, it doesn't go that route! I mean, sure, there's a lot of drama in later episodes, but not because of Charles being a romantic rival to Tada, he's a pretty chill dude who befriends even Tada quickly and never really tries to ruin his relationship with Teresa or anything, although he does genuinely love Teresa and is unaware that Alec has a crush on him. I would go as far as saying Charles is the true hero of this series, because if it wasn't for him, we would have gotten a much less predictable bittersweet ending.


... Well, when I put it like that, it makes Charles look like a character who just made the show more generic since the ending is exactly what I and everyone else were expecting it to be, but whatever, Charles is still a nice character for what this show is. Also, I don't really get the whole deal with Rainbow Shogun, this series dedicate a lot of screen time to this show and I don't really understand why, the rainbow color joke thing was funny the first time around, but not after it was repeated for the 20th time... Is there some deeper meaning to this? Is it just a running gag in the series? I don't know, maybe Rainbow Shogun is 2deep4me.


Anyway, I think you'll probably know what route Tada-kun takes and what kind of ending it will have by the time you're starting to watch the second half, it's awfully predictable and by-the-numbers, but it's not a bad anime, I didn't even have high expectations for it to begin with and got pleasantly surprised by how much I ended up liking some of its characters. I expected Tada-kun to be a nice little slice of life anime with bits of romance and comedy, and I got exactly what I expected, even if the writing is not exactly the greatest and it plays too safe for its own good, it was still enjoyable for what it was and the second half tackled the theme of regret over missed opportunities rather well. There's quite a handful of things to like about Tada-kun, depending on your expectations, your tolerance for clichés and predictable plot elements, you may even enjoy this show even more than I did, I would recommend giving at least the first three episodes a shot.

Every season has a warm slice of life anime and tada kun koi wa shinai is this season's soothing romance with a dash of comedy. Before it even aired i had lots of expectations. The summary sounded like it will be something new in contrast to regular romcoms. Granted it had an array of beautiful scenery, nice art and the animation is lovely.
But the title was as deceptive as the ending was predictably boring. While i had reservations regarding every episode as intensively childish, i had more such on the ending alone. I am still trying to wrap my mind around the conveniently ridiculousidea of how a princess of a small country goes off to japan with just a secretary and no guards? Her family like every other family in anime turned a blind eye to it because you either die or live to be invisible NPCs and are considered lucky to get a special mention. She randomly enrolled in a school which as per rules shall not verify the background of transfer students and gave the sole right of finding the secret to the hero/love interest. Being someone who watches anime, i have a watched a reasonable number of animus and it is baffled me when i see theresa knew only of "rainbow shogun" and for what it was worth, was insanely cheesy. 


Unfortunately there was no chemistry between Theresa and tada whatsoever. How could there be? Tada the quiet photograpy nerd was was too busy dwelling in his sad backstory to actually notice a girl much less fall in love. He was notoriously in need of the female interest to bring light to his soul.


This anime had some really funny romance in it. It went like this: Alec likes Charles , Charles likes Theresa,Theresa likes tada and apparently tada likes Theresa too. If you thought franxx was corny wait until you watch tada kun. 


I felt really sorry for Alec and Charles though. Even if he did let Theresa go there was no way he would pick Alec and sadly it should have been Alec and tada who were heart broken. Thanks to shoujo anime rule no 1- even if the MCs have no feelings for each other they will be forced to come together. 


When tada 'realized' his love for Theresa- whatever triggered it and went to the tiny nation, i was inwardly worried for the fate of this anime. i knew how it will go down.  

Anime logic is irrefutable as it glamours over the fact that tada and Theresa had been acquainted for not more than 2 seasons. 

Too bad Charles buckled. tada might have fought his fear and flown to Theresa. He might have battled against water current to retrieve the invite. He might have even mustered the courage to confess to an engaged princess. It still was not fair to Charles who had to give her up because the plot made him to do so. 


The plot was nothing far from ordinary with some outdoorsy activity and majority of which was cat chasing and photography. This anime had a cliched character line up. It was a cocktail of a brooding hero, a perverted and clueless senpai, one i look dowdy on outside but am foxy on the inside secret idol girl, a cute self obsessed best friend and a cat. Now the cat seemed to have hit it big. Add to this one cheerful but plain foreigner, a red head and a hot tall handsome guy. And the drink you get is "tada kun can fall in love"


What needed an explanation was why the hell does tada speak in Japanese to the castle guards? Even ijjuin uses english broken or otherwise.

The critic and me and the non critic in me are in very opposite ends for me in this show. on one hand i feel like compared to most other rom-com shows this one isn't as cliche as some of the other stuff i have seen (though it is still cliche). on the other hand i do feel like the story is pitifully average and sometimes boring at times. 
I don't want to talk much about the plot because honestly its pretty boring restating what i watched so i wont. Anyways, in terms of individuality or what i think that is unique to the show,i don't think there is much. I always thought the cast of characters was your average dumb anime cast, who always were oblivious to crucial plot points. I always thought the plot was so obvious that i could see the ending from episode one. though i cant say any spoilers i will say that it is painfully obvious right from the beginning what the main characters alter egos are. 



on the other hand the art and sound look fabulous. compared to other slice of life/ romance shows i have seen this one appears to have a much higher budget. it also has a really good and catchy opening that i would dumb sometimes. most of the time I skip intros, but this time i didn't most of the time. 



in terms of enjoyment while i shouldn't say that i should like it about a 6 or 5 i do decently like it kind of as a guilty pleasure. but, i do see where other people are coming from. this show is laughably predictable and average, and i know i said that it isn't that cliche compared to other shows, it still is very cliche. 6/10 better then average due to sound and looks but painfully average on story and character.

Story (4/10):
For me, the CONCEPT of what Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai is supposed to be (ie: a story about a teenager that never falls in love suddenly falling in love) was what had me interested in this show from the start. Unfortunately, I think it takes far too long to reach the point. It focuses on it a bit in the beginning, but as you continue watching it just seems to be about a group of friends more than a love story. While I have no problem with that either, I didn't start watching this because I wanted to see a story about friendships.Friendship is important even in a romance anime, but this just seems to be 95% friendship, 5% romance. I did only watch 4 episodes so I don't know if this improves later on, but I gave it a good 4 episode watch like I always do and I wasn't impressed.


Art (6/10):


The art itself isn't that bad. It's appealing to look at while not being anything overly special. Hence giving it one more point better than mediocre.


Sound (3/10):


To be honest I wasn't interested in the op or the ed. I don't even recall music in the actual anime itself that's how irrelevant it was to me. I can't say it was bad, but it wasn't anything I cared about or remember as important.


Character (5/10):


The characters themselves weren't horrible, but they were stereotypical and not very interesting to me. I didn't remember most of their names and I just found myself not being attracted to any of them. As someone who usually connects to characters in a matter of moments, this wasn't a good sign for me.


Enjoyment (4/10):


To be honest, I didn't even make it all the way through the fourth episode. I just marked myself as watching it because I watched half of it. It just seemed so... slow paced. I know slice of life shows are usually slow paced, but this one was in a way that I couldn't stand. I just found myself not enjoying it enough to get through the entire episode, but not enough to give it anything lower than a 4.


Overall (5/10):


Maybe it just wasn't my anime. Other people may enjoy it more than I did, but I still personally wouldn't recommend Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai to anyone who was interested in watching it. I really wanted to stand behind it, to hope that it would eventually get back to the point, but it didn't seem that way. I'm disappointed this one didn't turn out how I thought it would because it really did seem like one I'd enjoy.

I started watching "Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai" due to a recommendation, and thus expected something that would really catch my interest. However, five episodes in and I've realized that there's nothing particularly special about it at all.
Story: 5
It's the same thing you've seen again and again. A budding romance between the two main characters. Now, obviously this isn't always a bad thing, but the problem is that there's nothing that stands out. They have this element of photography in the series, but it's not a photography anime so it's usually just a plot device.
Art: 7
Episode 1 has some really pretty shots in it, butthat's the best it gets. The character designs are typical, but they are still well made and the backgrounds are good too.


Sound: 6

This may be an unpopular opinion, but the sound isn't great at all. I feel like the op and ed are things I've already heard before. Same with the soundtracks. Nothing stands out to me, but nothing is necessarily terrible.


Character: 6

I'll be honest, I would've given this category a lower score if not for Ijuuin. Just like the others, he fits into one of the generic tropes, but he is still hard to dislike. Despite being presented as the popular player type, that part of him actually takes a back seat to the fact that he is Tada's friend. On the other hand, I find Teresa to be completely unbearable. Although they continuously hint at her being a deeper character, we never actually experience it. Like most foreigner characters, she has learned Japanese almost perfectly, and yet her one defining factor is this undying love for Rainbow Shogun. In fact, this is all her character seems to revolve around, as she connects it to every single thing ever. Any sort of deeper understanding is completely overshadowed by this obsession, and she's supposed to be the main girl. 


Enjoyment: 5

I understand that this anime is supposed to give off a comfy feel to it, but I don't feel it at all. Every episode has something happen, only for it to not matter at all in any future episode. Every time I finish an episode, all I can think is, "Well, that's done." The funniest part of the show is Ijuuin being scared of Alexandra, and even that only gets a slight chuckle out of me. 


Overall: 6


I know there will be people who enjoy this show, and that's fine. It should be given a chance. Everyone has their own preferences. However, if you do not enjoy the most generic of generic, this show probably isn't for you. That's your warning. Obviously as more comes out, my opinions may change, but I don't expect this show to get much better than it already is. This show fails to do anything to stand out from the rest, but it's not garbage.

I actually liked the first episode of the series, thought it was going to focus on the photography aspects of love and romance, but as time goes on, I noticed something, this is basically every single cliche in romance plus comedy bundled into one, does not make it a bad thing.
