Rainbow Shogun got old the second weeb said it.

I had numerous problems while watching Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinmai, particularly the plot and characters. The plot is extremely transparent from the get go when we learn that Teresa is a princess and this is an romance anime. There were many avenues to go about this with, most which would probably have a better plot, however, they decide to go with a school slice of life which ramps from 0 to 100 within the last few episodes. Which such obvious cues, it made it hard to find myself invested within the story. Pacing issues and an uninteresting plot aside, the characters were extremely one-dimensional.The biggest offense is Tada, who is extremely boring and doesn't really do much unless the story demands him to do anything. Honestly, his only quirk is that he is a nice dude and when we compare him to Charles, who is nice and charismatic as well, frustrated me to no end knowing what they conclusion would probably have been. The supporting characters are full of 'one-trick ponies' and repeat the same jokes from the start to the finish. \n\n
Tada-kun wa Koi ao Shinmai, starts off pretty strong, however, it loses all of its momentum and becomes a pretty boring anime. The lack of a standout characters and a poorly paced plot really hindered this from becoming good. The ending also left a bitter feeling, as it does not feel deserved or conclusive about anything. I recommend watching something else as I feel that there are plenty of anime that do the same job better. I may seem like a happy ending hater but, IDGAF. Have a nice day.

Romance is my favorite gene so when i found Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai I was really happy. Finally another romance to watch! The question is.... was it good? Well I enjoyed well enough to give it a 7 so.... yeah it's good, but it is lacking so much. 
Story: 7/10
I believe it had a good story bases. Male who pushes is feelings a side, falls in love. Well the the problem is that it wasn't executed right. Story was supposed to be about a male Japaneses student named Tada, well it kinda took the back burner. Instead it felt like the story was focusedon the whole group and not Tada and his love interest Teresa. 


Characters: 5/10

We had a tone of characters in this anime, which sadly made it so we didn't get much character development. I kinda wish we didn't have all the other characters, especially the perverted weeb. If he wasn't in this I might have actually shown this to a couple people. 


Art: 8.5/10

Art was beautiful.




Final thoughts 

I feel that the ending was kinda rushed. I wish they give us another episode or if not that, give us a more sad ending.

Tada-kun wa Koi wo Shinai... First of all, the name of the series has nothing to do with the anime. Because, not even he does fall in love, but it was never part of his character trope to not fall in love with anyone, he just had better things to think before falling for someone.
With the synopsis, I expected more to be honest, the plot have some holes, and it was too cliché. Since it was an original anime we could forgive it for a bit, all the simpleness of the story. The first few episodes started great! But each episode, things were getting worse...and worse... until the last episode, the was a complete mess. Not artistically actually, overall the anime had a pretty decent animation that kept it's quality over all 13 episodes, with some really beautiful shots sometimes. 


To not be too critic, it did have some good points, the first 3/4 episodes were one,  a second was the animation that I already talked about, and the third were the sound, the ending was pretty generic, but it gets some points because it was a seiyuu that sang it. The opening was pretty satisfying too, I got myself singing it while listening. 


The characters were boring though, just like the pre-determined couples, only two of the four were quite interesting (and no, it wasn't the main characters one, they were the worst to be honest), they even teased one couple and they even didn't end up together! (I'm not going to say which though, that's for you to discover after you watched it) (But guess what? It was my favorite one...). Teresa had a predictable history, and Tada-kun a boring, overused one.


From all the characters, the best one were Tada-kun's sister, Mitsuyoshi (that surprisingly had some depth in it, the character that everyone saw as the fool had one of the best developments), hell even the old man that owned the shop was more likable than the main characters!


After all this criticism I still gave it a 7 for the enjoyment, I had quite the fun watching it, but still I was expecting much more from it. Overall I give it a 6, too much cliché and overused tropes, but decent sound and animation, if you forget about Teresa and Tada-kun everything seems quite good actually! (Am I talking about SAO here? haha...) 


I recommend to watch it when you just want a cheesy, romance anime to pass your time, don't expect a masterpiece like Gekkan Shoujo Nozaki-kun, or a good romance develpment like Sukitte Ii na Yo (though many disagree with me in this)

NON SPOILER REVIEW  
I have just finished watching this anime, here is my review fresh off my mind.
WHAT I LIKED
This was a simple 13 episode rom-com anime that was enjoyable to watch. The story was pretty generic, but at the end of the day, you are pretty satisfied with all that is said and done by the main and side character(s). This is an original anime meaning there is no adaptation to follow on. It may be a strength or weakness, but the watchers will have some peace of mind that whatever comes after the ending is up to the imaginations of the watcherswhether it is happy or sad. The art was fantastic and the animations had the quality of a top studio production. The drama shown in  the anime was good to keep me watching episode by episode and many people I feel could relate to the events pertaining to the main characters. One of the best things I like in this anime was the amount of symbolism you can find if you look between the lines and how it describes the development and regrets of our main characters.     


What I disliked


The pacing of the story was very slow in the beginning few episodes. It feels like some of the episodes were "fillers" even though they were not. I would have liked to see more development between characters in these episodes, especially on the main romantic interests. The romance between these two main characters seems to have just popped out in 1 episode rather than accumulating over a long period of time. There were many times the cat would take place to break the ice (comedic relief) and I thought that there could be more romantic development in these places.  Due to this, at the end of the anime, I come out wondering if the romance was more like a high school "spur of the moment" kind of event rather than true love. There was also a lot of lost potential in this anime. As many reviewers said, it could have been much better and I agree. I wish they developed more on the photography aspect of the anime but I feel as if I was sold short as photography does have symbolism in the anime but wasn't the main part of the story.         



Should you watch it


If you want to watch a short anime that has a generic story line but is enjoyable to watch, I highly recommend it. Although this anime isn't something you'll have a thousand words about, this also isn't an anime you'll watch as say "This was a waste of my time." I do believe that this anime do have its own merits and strengths and if you can look past all of its faults, you have an enjoyable rom-com story you'll surely laugh and be happy with.

"Tada-Kun Never Falls In Love" has no business being good. It borrows some of the oldest tropes in the book, its 'plot twists' can be seen a mile away, and calling much of anything about it original would lead me to think you REALLY don't watch much romance in any medium. And yet... you end up enjoying it. It can be strangely charming, perhaps simply because it has no pretensions of being anything other than what it is and plays it straight.
She's a bubbly, naive princess trying to get outside of her sheltered royal life, he's a jaded, more mature guy, they meet and boththeir lives change. Stop me if you've heard this one before. OK, you probably have- Tada-Kun has some striking resemblances to a famous old black-and-white American romantic film called 'Roman Holiday'. The OP even includes a brief clip of Tada and Teresa on a Vespa scooter that directly references the most iconic scene of the film. Maybe that's what let me let my guard down with this show, it quietly acknowledged what it was going for and didn't put on any airs. Now granted, if you don't accept this series for what it is you probably won't be following along for very long. There isn't much comedy that goes beyond getting a chuckle (except for a brilliant gag involving a Golgo 13 reference of all things), and towards the end it can be plenty melodramatic.


Now while animation is fairly standard, the aesthetic is quite nice. It has a vaguely pastel look that can be quite soothing and the character designs, while they follow well-worn archetypes are nice enough. Sound is a flat 5 here, I don't remember any of it for good or bad. The characters are also nothing you haven't seen before. For example, Tada's two best friends are the comic relief guy and the girl-crazed horndog senpai, two archetypes who are practically obligated to appear in every anime love story until Japan sinks back into the Pacific Ocean. Also, Hinako must be ordering her eye glass from the same place Superman gets his...


I don't know how they did it, but 'Tada-Kun' on paper did everything wrong... but still came out alright.

All the chatter I heard about this show was mixed, it was mainly positive, but after watching it, I can see why.
Tada is by no means a bad show, but it does have some serious flaws that also hold it back for me to call it a good show as well. Firstly, it's full of romance, and anime cliches which do not automatically disqualify it from getting a good score from me especially if you have a creative way of using those clique's, or have an enjoyable cast to offset that. 
Tada does have a fairly strong cast I enjoyed, but there a couple ofweak members who are kind of important........... THE MAIN FRICKING LEADS/ROMANTIC COUPLE. It's not that they are entirely bad per se, but throughout the show, I never felt they had any chemistry, which is vital for a show that has its main focus as romance. 


Also to resolve the central romance at the end of the show they kind of shelf any conclusion for any of the other potential couples in the series which ticked me off particularly with Pin and Hana's relationship, because I wanted some resolution there.


Some Points I will give to this show's favor the art is way above industry standard and instead of doing the fiance is a total prick he is actually a really cool guy.


Edit: So after last season and simmering on my thoughts of the show after a while I have to downgrade the show a point as I feel it no longer deserves that high a rating.

IMO, if this anime was released like a few years back, I think it'll get a score of 8.
This anime reminds me slightly of Tsuki ga Kirei. Probably due to its story progression a bit similar to each other. 
Story:
I've seen this kind of plot being abused mostly by harem animes. I don't remember watching an anime which actually takes this kind of plot up to the next level until I found this. (i forgot but whatever)
In this anime, its plot was modified to be logical as possible for most scenes. Any yee-yee-ass anime will make the MC or any character do something cool orWTF and you wouldn't do the same shit in real life don't you? As if you're that lucky. LOL.


The story progression is smooth, every episode end left me wanting to know more. You'll see mostly generic stuff/scenes/incident thorughout the storyline which basically you'd already seen in most rom-com anime. I know its overused, but at least this anime is able to present it better than I expected.


Art:

MC reminds of Gekkan Shoujo's MC.

Teresa reminds me of Kato from Saekano.


But nonetheless, no complain about art or animations. They look refined yet simple. I'm not saying similar looking characters are bad, its just that it 'look' similar. That's all. 


Sound:

I think the OP could be more better with this type of anime. Don't know about the lyrics though, but overall, I'd say OK. 


No complain about SFX, I think it did a great job on hooking myself to the character's real time emotion.


Character:

This is a peaceful anime. I didn't find any villain or 'bad' guy in this one lol. Even if there is one, he's very understandable. If it were the animes I watched previously, expect some useless fights or wars. 


As usual, most noticeable character development was the MC and Teresa. Others might have though but not that deep and they only showed some history flashbacks and so on. 


Enjoyment:

The way this anime presents the character's story lives actually had me going. There are times you'll feel happy or sad together with the characters itself. Love it.


Overall:

I'll try my best to say as accurately as I can on what would you get in this anime.


- Expect some cliché stuffs BUT, with a good presentation

- The characters are so gentle which I think this anime is good if you're looking for relaxing anime with no misunderstandings or fights. (even if there is, its not that big anyways lol)

- Story progression is slightly similar to Tsuki ga Kirei.

- Ending? It doesn't make you cry. That's all I can say. Go watch & judge for youselves

While a 7 out of 10 is nothing to scoff at, part of me is genuinely disappointed I couldn’t give this an 8. It’s been awhile since I’ve seen an entirely original romance anime. No manga or light novel to work off of or use as a template. However, Tada Never Falls in Love (or just Tadakoi) in no way feels original. I’ve seen plenty of romance anime and it honestly just felt like I’ve seen most of the romantic development before. Even worse, the central romance of the anime didn’t really get any focus until Episodes 6 and 8-13. Episodes 1-5 and 7 weremostly dedicated to either casual Slice of Life antics (Which isn’t bad by all means) or romantic sub-plots that don’t go anywhere. I truly feel like Tadakoi should’ve been 24 episodes long. It felt like it wanted to accomplish too much within the 13 episodes it had to work with. While the romance was fairly cliche and the slice of life segments weren’t anything special, Tadakoi is still a good anime. It uses all the good cliches at the very least, so there’s nothing aggravating about the anime for the most part. The characters were simply good. Nothing great or memorable, but solid nonetheless. Tada was quiet and rather stoic for a main character but still a very chill guy, Teresa was a lovable love interest, Ijuuin was voiced by Mamoru Miyano so he half stole the show, half got a bit too much at times (Like most of Miyano’s roles to be honest.) The rest of the cast weren’t anything worth mentioning as they didn’t really add much. There was a decent romantic subplot between Pin-senpai and Hinako (Friends of Tada and company in the Photography Club) but the anime essentially ran out of time for them. That entire subplot was forgotten by the anime in favor of the two main characters after Episode 8. As your standard slice of life school anime, the first 5-6 episodes are good. However, knowing full well that it’s a romance anime, it started to get a bit old. I wanted to see the development of the main romance, but it got pushed farther and farther back right until the very end. Speaking of, I won’t completely spoil the ending, but god damn it, I’m disappointed with it. It had everything perfectly set up for an unique ending, but settled for being generic at the LITERAL last minute. For me, it managed to raise more questions than answers. While the animation was gorgeous at times and accompanied by a very good soundtrack, Tadakoi is ultimately generic story wise. It’s a romance anime you’ve probably seen countless times before, but it’s fairly difficult to hate. Not a whole lot to love, but far from being average.

Well, nothing new to be found here. Tada-kun is your averange, run-of-the-mill romance anime with the average, run-of-the-mill plotpoints and twists. Seriously, stop me if you've ever heard this one (Spoilers):
- Boy meets girl
- Girl is incredibly good looking
- She is also the new exchange student in boys class
- She also now lives next to boy for her stay in Japan
Predictable. Utterly, utterly predictable. 
HOWEVER, this is, in fact, not a bad anime. It's above average actually. 
I really like the shows simplistic, yet not ugly drawing style and sometimes you can see small details of backstory scattered here and there. For example, pay closeattention to the young couple of episode one, since this is not the last appearance they make in the anime. Or the mean looking dude who resembles the main character in a show an awful lot. \n\n
The endingsong is nice, and soothing the kind that makes you feel all warm and fuzzy inside, while the opening gives off happy, feel good vibes. \n\n
The characters are not annoying and are all fun to watch. I feel like one might could've expanded on their storys or their afterstorys a bit, but ey, it's 13 episodes, what are you gonna do? \n\n
While it's true that this show brings almost nothing new to the table, I can recommend it to anyone looking for a short and sweet romancestory that one can breeze through in a couple of hours. \n\n

(This review contains light spoilers)
This anime could have been good, but it came out to be slow and rushed, at the same time. 
Slow because the development of the relationship of the characters was lacking, but magically at episode 9 or 10 they have to (expressly) tell us that they're in love, obviously something that could have been said by the story itself if it was well written.
And rushed because the last 2 episodes are SO dramatic, but in a bad way, they barely express anything in 11 episodes and suddenly BOOM everything in your face. The element of Ijuin being a "comedy relief" doesn'tmake it better, because it take away any sense of seriousness that drama could have had. \n
All in all, I feel like they had interesting characters but made nothing out of it.\n
The animation is poor and the music is forgettable.\n
If you're looking for a romantic anime, I would not recommend this one.

Story: The Story revolves around to transfer students from another country to study abroad. Where they meet our main hero Tada who never falls in love. Okay so it's not all that but there really is not much to this story. There's a huge cast of characters who you think will be developed into some kind of romantic story but it ends up being an anime focused Heavily on an Overweight cat (The best character) and the results of falling in love with....well spoilers...royalty.
Art: The art and animation was average at best. it was clean and crisp but nothing over-the-top.
Sound and Music: The opening wassuper fun, and the music throughout the anime was very chill.


Characters: They needed more development. I mean were we supposed to understand each one of their past experiences just by the opening video? These were interesting characters but nothing overly special besides Nyanko Big. 


Enjoyment: I enjoyed it enough to the point where I did not want to drop it. 


Overall: I feel as though if you started this anime it's not the worst thing in the world to finish. However I would not recommend it to anyone looking for a romance anime.

This anime reminds me of any Jane Austen novel: the base recipe is something you've seen before with some flavourful details that you haven't. Most of the time it's just the right degree of cheesy for a RomCom but occasionally it slips and gets a bit too cliché. 
The plot has it's weaknesses and a lot of potential for eyerolling. At times it feels like two stories made into one. The japanese Characters, especially Tada-kun and his family are well designed, thought through personalities - Teresa and Alec are more one dimensional and bland just as the plot parts they drive. [Spoiler]It feels like theywasted a nice story setting and good initial character design on a really bad princess-lovestory.\n\n
I have extremely mixed feelings about this anime. It looks pretty and it's hard not to have a crush on Mitsuyoshi and the adorable family coffee shop but since everything evolves around Teresa and everything about Teresa is boring and "seen" I'm ultimately let down. Never thought I'd say that but the fantasy elements are totally ruining a good slice of life anime.

Loving the anime so far. OP and ED songs are great. Characters are well designed with similarities to other animes here and there but that's fine. The general feel of the show is pleasant and the male protagonist is ver calm and collected like I always prefer. There is mostly comedy with good romance and little drama too. The conversation between Alec and Ijuin is hilarious. It also has one perverted character which is always nice for that adult factor. The art is well done and voice cast is superb too. This revolves mostly around photography and they have a club for that too. Willupdate as I watch it.
